AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States/Mexican Border Patrol: conducted a roving stop of the large white Ford pickup truck and patrols a 140-mile area of the United States/Mexican border, involved in surveillance and pursuit of suspicious vehicles, conducted a stop, makes temporary investigative stops based on reasonable suspicion, had reason to believe that the large white Ford pickup truck had recently crossed the United States/Mexican border, has agents with experience detecting illegal activity in the United States/Mexican border area, drew inferences from historical facts and events leading up to a stop, includes agents such as Andrew P. Graham and Jay Snodgrass who have experience in narcotics and alien smuggling cases
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Big Bend National Park: location where park visitors were observed, location where a suspicious work vehicle was seen, national park located on the United States/Mexican border where vehicle sensors are located, source of tourist traffic, possible transit point for smugglers, has usual traffic patterns with light traffic before six o'clock in the morning, two vehicles passed a sensor within the park, hires contractors from the Alpine, Texas area
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Marfa Sector Area Operations Center: operations center for Border Patrol activities that notified agents about vehicle sensor activations, previously served by Jay Snodgrass before transferring to Alpine, Texas, notified Agents Andrew P. Graham and Jay Snodgrass through Marfa Sector Area Operations Center Communications, involved in surveillance of the large white Ford pickup truck
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States: country involved in the border issue, noted suspicious behavior in the context of border patrol stops
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.District Court: court that denied the motion to suppress, analyzes reasonable suspicion in border patrol stops, found that the totality of the circumstances provided Andrew P. Graham and Jay Snodgrass with reasonable suspicion to warrant the stop of the large white Ford pickup truck, determined proximity-to-the-border element supported reasonable suspicion
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States/Mexican border: geographic location relevant to the case, proximity to which may contribute to reasonable suspicion, seventy-five miles from where the stop occurred
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.5th Circuit Court: court that established guidelines for reasonable suspicion in border patrol stops
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States/Mexican Border: geographic location relevant to the case, proximity to which may contribute to reasonable suspicion
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.U.S. District Court: made a factual determination regarding the application of a two-level upward adjustment for possession of a weapon in connection with a drug trafficking offense, reviews decisions for clear error, considers PSR as evidence in making factual determinations required by sentencing guidelines, affirmed Brignoni-Ponce Jacquinot's conviction and sentence
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Government: responsible for proving by a preponderance of the evidence that a temporal and spatial relation existed between a weapon and a drug trafficking offense, has the burden of proof under guidelines
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Judge Robert M. Parker: judge who specially concurred with the decision, recognizing the current state of jurisprudence regarding the war on drugs, expressed hope for a return to reason in the approach to the war on drugs
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Texas Highway 385: a smuggling route with heavy traffic from tourists visiting Big Bend National Park, but typically light traffic before six o'clock in the morning, known for alien and narcotics smuggling, has seen an increase in alien and smuggling apprehensions due to enhanced enforcement on other nearby highways
